name: 4'-(methylthio)acetophenone
Reason: 4'-(methylthio)acetophenone has a melting point that we can compare to benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The basic unit for our comparison will be benzene. The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of a methylthio group, which introduces a sulfur atom and the associated rigid structure, estimated at around +10 °C. Additionally, the methyl group introduces a small increase in molecular weight and possible hydrogen bonding, estimated at around +5 °C. The acetophenone group also contributes to the melting point due to its ability to form hydrogen bonds, estimated at around +10 °C. The methylthio group introduces a sulfur atom, which can participate in hydrogen bonding and rigidify the structure, estimated at around +10 °C.
